newsitem.title: USA: California plans to sue tobacco industry Thursday.
newsitem.headline: California plans to sue tobacco industry Thursday.

text.p: California's attorney general is expected Thursday to sue major tobacco companies to recoup public health-care costs related to smoking, state sources said.
California, the most populous state, with billions of dollars in potential claims, has watched from the sidelines for three years as other states have taken legal action.
But pressure has been building on state Attorney General Dan Lungren in recent months to join the fight.
State sources said Lungren plans to file the state's tobacco lawsuit this week, most likely on Thursday.
His spokesman, Rob Stutzman, would only say that Lungren would "make an announcement regarding tobacco tomorrow."
Oregon and Idaho sued tobacco companies Tuesday, bringing to 36 the number of states seeking restitution for health care costs related to illness allegedly caused by smoking.
Lungren, a Republican, has long asserted that a lawsuit by California against tobacco companies would fail because of a 1987 state law shielding them from product liability claims.
Earlier this year, state Assembly Speaker Cruz Bustamante, a Democrat, introduced legislation to remove that barrier and clear the way for Lungren to sue the tobacco industry.
The state Senate and Assembly both approved the bill last week, sending it to Republican Gov. Pete Wilson for review.
Wilson plans to sign the bill at a news conference in Los Angeles Thursday and to call on Lungren to file the state's suit immediately, said Wilson's spokeswoman, Lisa Kalustian.
"This is certainly important for the state of California," Kalustian said of the tobacco bill. "The governor's going to sign this bill tomorrow."
Once signed into law by Wilson, Bustamante's legislation would take effect immediately.
Lungren has already reached a settlement with tobacco company Brooke Group Ltd. to recoup health care costs.

Under terms of that settlement, Brooke, parent of Liggett Tobacco Co., has agreed to reimburse California for public health costs incurred as a result of smoking as well as providing internal documents that could help the state sue others in the tobacco industry.

In their own legal assault, 13 California counties, two cities, and the city and county of San Francisco have already sued major tobacco companies in state court. A similar lawsuit by the local governments was filed in federal court to recover their health-care costs.
